headline: Trump's Dr. Oz Endorsement Is Proving Controversial
author: John Johnson
sentences: Politico quotes him in a recent podcast: "How does Dr. Oz, probably the most anti-MAGA guy, and you got Fox non-stop pimping this guy out and Newsmax pimping this guy out, and that’s what it is—how does Dr. Oz, from New Jersey ... become a factor in a Senate race in the commonwealth of Pennsylvania?” Roger Stone also questioned the pick on Telegram, posting a photo of Oz on his former TV show with Michelle Obama, per the Daily Beast.

"I think that President Trump very, very seldom does anything that's not thought out and doesn't have a very reasoned and logical basis, but, for whatever reason, in this particular instance, he chose to ignore all of that."

"The larger implication of this is that Donald Trump may very well be in danger of losing some of the mojo he’s had to keep an iron grip on the Republican Party since he ran for president and won," he writes.
Taking advantage: Despite all the criticism above, a recent Emerson College poll suggested that 60% of primary voters in Pennsylvania would back a candidate who had Trump's blessing.
A warning: "This endorsement could divide MAGA in the only way that matters: (Trump) could lose America First conservatives over it," writes Joel Pollak of Breitbart.

A look at coverage:
Criticism: A common refrain among critics is that Oz is not sufficiently conservative and has not been a reliable supporter of the MAGA movement.
At the Daily Beast, Matt Lewis is struck by the widespread criticism among Trump supporters, even though most seem to be blaming advisers rather than Trump himself.
As "people on the right begin to normalize criticizing Trump (albeit, couched in rhetoric blaming others), another possibility opens up: Moving on from Trump."
But this endorsement is shaping up to be a relatively controversial one among Trump supporters, many of whom favored a rival candidate named David McCormick.
(Newser) – Over the weekend, former President Trump endorsed Mehmet Oz—better known to Americans as Dr. Oz—in the GOP Senate primary in Pennsylvania.
Oz plans a major TV advertising push, his biggest to date, to make sure Pennsylvanians know Trump has endorsed him, reports NBC News.
The issue is that the former president no longer has the voice he once had given that he's barred from Twitter and Facebook.
If so, "it will call into question whether inhabiting Trump’s universe and trying to get close to him is worth it at all.
The former president is famously impervious to criticism, of course, but Lewis wonders if this batch signals a shift.
Ditto: Daniel Strauss at the New Republic assesses the endorsement as well as others by Trump in this cycle.
“President Trump was very out of sync in picking Oz," says Dave Ball, GOP chairman in Washington County.
"For Trump the world is split between those who can do things for him and those who can't," he writes.
McCormick is a solid conservative candidate and his wife, Dina, served in the Trump administration.
McCormick, for example, remains ahead in the polls for now and could well win the primary.
"Oz, because he was on TV, can win—and by winning that makes Donald Trump look good.
Chris Cillizza of CNN says the clincher was the heart surgeon's TV fame.
The more that’s put into question, the more it’s a disaster for Trump."
(Bannon's Fox reference is likely to Sean Hannity, a big Oz backer.)
The Washington Examiner rounds up sentiment in Pennsylvania itself.
So, voila, Trump endorses Oz."
(Read more Dr. Oz stories.)
Steve Bannon also hates it.
So why pick Oz?
Bad for Trump?
So why Oz?
Solution?
